title: SeaWorld Entertainment CEO Resigns After Seven Months
text:
SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. SEAS -0.03% said Monday that Chief Executive Gustavo Antorcha is leaving the company, seven months after taking the helm.

The amusement park chain named Marc Swanson, its current chief financial officer, as its interim CEO, while Elizabeth Castro Gulacsy, the company’s chief accounting officer, will become interim CFO.

Attempts to reach Mr. Antorcha weren’t immediately successful, but in prepared remarks he said, “While I may have a difference of approach, I continue to believe in SeaWorld’s strategy, mission, team and prospects.”

SeaWorld said in February that it had hired Mr. Antorcha, the former chief operating officer of Carnival Cruise Lines, a unit of Carnival Corp.

SeaWorld has dealt with a spate of leadership changes in the past few years as it works to move past the fallout the documentary “Blackfish” had on its business.

In February 2018, CEO Joel Manby stepped down, as attendance fell and its losses widened. The company then appointed SeaWorld Chief Parks Operations Officer John Reilly, who had been with the company for more than 30 years, as interim CEO.

In naming Mr. Antorcha as its CEO in February 2019, the company also named Mr. Reilly as its chief operating officer, but he resigned from the company in March.

Also, over the summer, Yoshikazu Maruyama resigned as chairman, citing “outside professional obligations.” He remains a member of the board and was replaced by Scott Ross as chairman.

Mr. Swanson has been with SeaWorld for 19 years and served as the company’s chief financial officer.

In August, the marine theme park company renewed its stock buyback program and its second-quarter earnings topped analysts’ estimates.

Shares of SeaWorld fell 1.9% in after-hours trading. The stock is up 36% so far this year.

Write to Kimberly Chin at kimberly.chin@wsj.com
